BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 16, 1921
WHAT WILL CONSTITUTE SUCCESS AT THE WASHINGTON
CONFERENCE?
The Conference on the Limitation of Armaments was called for
but one object. That object, which has never been realized before,
has been sought for ever since history first began to write itself. That
object is a universal, a permanent peace. But peace can only be
maintained by the good-will and faith among those with whom it
rests. The purpose of this conference, then, is to aid in the formidable task of crystallizing international confidence. There are two
means of doing this—the limitation of armaments and the decisive
settlement of those problems of the Far East which have been clamoring for attention and solution for the past thirty years. The sm.cess of this conference, then, will depend entirely on the settlement of
these two issues.
Some definite conclusion must be reached in regard to the situation in Eastern Asia. There must be more light, more order, in
Eastern affairs. Definite policies must be established. A logical and
probable conclusion will be that an international policy will be
adopted to preserve the integrity of China as the essential basis of
world peace. The burden of enforcing this policy would rest with all
nations. This world interest, however, must be reconciled with Japan's national needs. Finally there must be substituted in future
Asiatic affairs a spirit of understanding and confidence rather than
the past deliberate misunderstanding and violence.
With the calling together of delegates from all parts of the world
to the Peace Conference, a new and better moral atmosphere is already pervading the minds of peoples and rulers. A proposed and
comparatively permanent reaction has at last set in against the politics of force in accomplishing necessary or desirable political objects. This improvement is increasing not only in volume, but in
positive achievement.
The Hughes proposals are the expression of a new spirit in international affairs. Armaments are merely one expression of forceful
politics and they are universally associated with defensive alliances,
secret diplomacy, strategic frontiers, economic exclusiveness and
national egotism. They are the mouth and branch of all that which
civilization and progress are decreeing must go. The whole wretched
disgusting pot-pouri must be outlawed.
Disarmament is the major issue. It must put an actual and
effective stop to the competition of building war machines on earth
and sea. Economically it will save the world from possible bankruptcy, but, more important than ever, it will remove the primary germs of hostile feeling between states. Physical disarmament is not enough. It is not an end but a means—a means toward
moral disarmament and a general atmosphere of peace. It is by the
realization that arms are hostile to amicable feeling and that their
absence causes that to be forgotten for which they stand, that is
bringing about disarmament today.
When the Washington Conference has accomplished these two
things its mission is fulfilled. It has succeeded in that which it has
undertaken. What it has done, however, is not the goal, not the aim,
not the end. It is but the first step forward toward better feeling,
good-will, faith and confidence among nations. Where it may lead,
no one knows—perhaps an association of nations, perhaps in the dim
distant future the dreamed of World State—the "Parliament of Man,
the Federation of the World."

Today at 12.30 the annual "Tap
Day" of the Cane Club will take
place. The initiates will be lined
up before Gilman Hall at that
time and the club will approach in
its customary chariots, hearses,
shays, etc. After the impressive
ceremony, which follows, is completed the club will take lunch at
the College Inn. Tonight a dance
will also be given in honor of the
new members at L'Hirondelle
Club.
Students may be well reminded
what a momentous and impressive
ceremony "Tap Day" is. To explain for the sake of the ignorant,
what Skull and Keys is to Yale,
the Cane Club is to Hopkins and
what "Tap Day" is here, "Tap
Election to its

schools of his native land, English
as well as Spanish is taught
which was of material aid to those

URING the last twenty-five years power
generation practice has been revolutionized. The steam turbine has definitely displaced the reciprocating engine as the standard
prime mover in large generating equipments.
And Francis Hodgkinson has had more to do
with this achievement than any other one individual.
Mr. Hodgkinson came to this country along
with the Westinghouse Licenses under the Parsons patents, in 1896, upon the recommendation
of the inventor himself. Since that time practically every commercial steam turbine Westinghouse has built has been designed and built by
him and his able associates.
In this quarter-century of steam-turbine development inventive genius has been paralleled
throughout by practical level-headedness. There
are few cases in engineering history where the
record is writ as clearly and impressively as this.
There can be nothing but credit for the engineer
who puts his errors underfoot and rises upon
them, and most of the world's greatest achievements have been so reached. The World also

D

honors progress that is surefooted and far-visioned, such as the development of steam turbines
under Mr. Hodgkinson's direction.
Many inventions of tremendous value in
steam turbine practice have been devised and
perfected by him and his co-workers. Among
the more important of these are the construction, in 1907, of the first low-pressure turbine to
be built in America, and in 1911, of the first
Bleeder type of turbine; the perfection, in company with H. E. Longwell, of the water-seal
gland; a balancing machine for turbine rotors
that is almost superhumanly sensitive; a troubleproof method of supporting turbine cylinders;
and a very superior process for affixing turbine
blades to rotor and cylinder.
One of the fundamental Westinghouse policies is insistence upon the uttermost in engineering. The observance of this policy in form and
in spirit has provided genuine opportunities for
many men of remarkable engineering gifts, one
of the most notable of whom is the man whose
name appears as the title of this article, Francis
Hodgkinson.

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 16, 1921
WHAT WILL CONSTITUTE SUCCESS AT THE WASHINGTON
CONFERENCE?
The Conference on the Limitation of Armaments was called for
but one object. That object, which has never been realized before,
has been sought for ever since history first began to write itself. That
object is a universal, a permanent peace. But peace can only be
maintained by the good-will and faith among those with whom it
rests. The purpose of this conference, then, is to aid in the formidable task of crystallizing international confidence. There are two
means of doing this—the limitation of armaments and the decisive
settlement of those problems of the Far East which have been clamoring for attention and solution for the past thirty years. The sm.cess of this conference, then, will depend entirely on the settlement of
these two issues.
Some definite conclusion must be reached in regard to the situation in Eastern Asia. There must be more light, more order, in
Eastern affairs. Definite policies must be established. A logical and
probable conclusion will be that an international policy will be
adopted to preserve the integrity of China as the essential basis of
world peace. The burden of enforcing this policy would rest with all
nations. This world interest, however, must be reconciled with Japan's national needs. Finally there must be substituted in future
Asiatic affairs a spirit of understanding and confidence rather than
the past deliberate misunderstanding and violence.
With the calling together of delegates from all parts of the world
to the Peace Conference, a new and better moral atmosphere is already pervading the minds of peoples and rulers. A proposed and
comparatively permanent reaction has at last set in against the politics of force in accomplishing necessary or desirable political objects. This improvement is increasing not only in volume, but in
positive achievement.
The Hughes proposals are the expression of a new spirit in international affairs. Armaments are merely one expression of forceful
politics and they are universally associated with defensive alliances,
secret diplomacy, strategic frontiers, economic exclusiveness and
national egotism. They are the mouth and branch of all that which
civilization and progress are decreeing must go. The whole wretched
disgusting pot-pouri must be outlawed.
Disarmament is the major issue. It must put an actual and
effective stop to the competition of building war machines on earth
and sea. Economically it will save the world from possible bankruptcy, but, more important than ever, it will remove the primary germs of hostile feeling between states. Physical disarmament is not enough. It is not an end but a means—a means toward
moral disarmament and a general atmosphere of peace. It is by the
realization that arms are hostile to amicable feeling and that their
absence causes that to be forgotten for which they stand, that is
bringing about disarmament today.
When the Washington Conference has accomplished these two
things its mission is fulfilled. It has succeeded in that which it has
undertaken. What it has done, however, is not the goal, not the aim,
not the end. It is but the first step forward toward better feeling,
good-will, faith and confidence among nations. Where it may lead,
no one knows—perhaps an association of nations, perhaps in the dim
distant future the dreamed of World State—the "Parliament of Man,
the Federation of the World."

URING the last twenty-five years power
generation practice has been revolutionized. The steam turbine has definitely displaced the reciprocating engine as the standard
prime mover in large generating equipments.
And Francis Hodgkinson has had more to do
with this achievement than any other one individual.
Mr. Hodgkinson came to this country along
with the Westinghouse Licenses under the Parsons patents, in 1896, upon the recommendation
of the inventor himself. Since that time practically every commercial steam turbine Westinghouse has built has been designed and built by
him and his able associates.
In this quarter-century of steam-turbine development inventive genius has been paralleled
throughout by practical level-headedness. There
are few cases in engineering history where the
record is writ as clearly and impressively as this.
There can be nothing but credit for the engineer
who puts his errors underfoot and rises upon
them, and most of the world's greatest achievements have been so reached. The World also

D

honors progress that is surefooted and far-visioned, such as the development of steam turbines
under Mr. Hodgkinson's direction.
Many inventions of tremendous value in
steam turbine practice have been devised and
perfected by him and his co-workers. Among
the more important of these are the construction, in 1907, of the first low-pressure turbine to
be built in America, and in 1911, of the first
Bleeder type of turbine; the perfection, in company with H. E. Longwell, of the water-seal
gland; a balancing machine for turbine rotors
that is almost superhumanly sensitive; a troubleproof method of supporting turbine cylinders;
and a very superior process for affixing turbine
blades to rotor and cylinder.
One of the fundamental Westinghouse policies is insistence upon the uttermost in engineering. The observance of this policy in form and
in spirit has provided genuine opportunities for
many men of remarkable engineering gifts, one
of the most notable of whom is the man whose
name appears as the title of this article, Francis
Hodgkinson.
